thread.title: Vic rape trial dropped against Wild family - 9news.com.au
thread.title_full: Vic rape trial dropped against Wild family - 9news.com.au

title: Vic rape trial dropped against Wild family - 9news.com.au
text:
Vic rape trial dropped against Wild family By AAP 
A trial against two brothers and a third relative over allegations they raped a 14-year-old Victorian girl will not go ahead amid concerns about the complainant's wellbeing. 
But the decision to discontinue the prosecution does not mean they have been acquitted. 
Brothers Kevin Andrew Wild, 31, and Allan Mark Wild, 30, and their relative Brodie Mark Wild were due to stand trial in March over charges they raped the girl in 2015. 
But counsel for the Director of Public Prosecutions on Friday told the Victorian Supreme Court that the case would be discontinued. 
Lesley Taylor QC also told the court that details about the alleged offences should remain suppressed to protect "an extremely vulnerable" girl. 
An affidavit by the complainant's mother was tendered in court, with Ms Taylor requesting it not be made public. 
According to the Criminal Procedure Act 2009, a discontinuance of prosecution "does not amount to an acquittal." 
The act also says a person can still face a charge whose prosecution has been discontinued. 
"An accused may be indicted on a charge in respect of which an earlier prosecution has been discontinued." 
Only the Director of Public Prosecutions can make decisions about discontinuances. 
The Wilds were charged over the alleged rape in Geelong in November 2015. 
Brodie Wild, 21, was extradited from Queensland to face the charges but was allowed to return home on bail. 
Allan Wild and his brother Kevin spent time in custody before both were released on bail in 2016. 
All three pleaded not guilty to the charges against them after they were committed to stand trial for the alleged rape in June 2016. 
At a directions hearing on February 2 about the upcoming rape trial, a counsel for one of the three accused Wild relatives flagged an application to apply for separate trials. 
Prosecutors said they would oppose the applications. 
The matter was adjourned for further mention on Friday, with prosecutors then filing a notice of discontinuation. Â© AAP 2017
